text.p: FAI Insurances Ltd said on Wednesday the first four months of the 1996/97 (July-June) financial year had been profitable.

"The first four months have beeen profitable. You will appreciate that these figures are only early indicators and developments during the year may have a material effect," FAI chairman John Landerer told the company's annual general meeting.
FAI reported a A$10.04 million net profit in the year to June 30, 1996 from a loss of A$89.84 million the previous year.
On October 25, FAI managing director Rodney Adler told Reuters FAI was ahead of budget in the quarter to September 30.
Landerer said today FAI was anticipating further reductions in the compulsory third party (CPT) underwriting losses in the current year.
"A number of initiatives were introduced into our CTP division to improve profitabiltity which included changing the mix of business both at the new business and renewal stages," Landerer said.
FAI had noticed a substantial softening in the commercial insurance market during the past year, Landerer said.
"Most rates have fallen, with some companies being particularly aggressive in chasing new business," he said.
FAI had chosen to place greater emphasis on the control and underwriting of quality business, rather than reducing prices, Landerer said.
FAI's home insurance business had continued to improve.
"A new range of products has recently been released which seeks to appeal to a much wider cross section of the community," he said.
Landerer said FAI's wholly-owned St Moritz hotel in New York had its strongest year since its acquisition in early 1990.
"Indications are that the current level of demand should be sustained throughout 1997," he said.
FAI shares were one cent lower at 69 cents at 11.20 a.m. (0020 GMT).
